awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A Non-thermal Plasma Reactor System for Destruction of Particulate Matter in High-Temperature Diesel Exhaust
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to eliminate more than 95% of particulate emissions (i.e., carbon soot) from diesel exhaust while reducing fuel usage, carbon dioxide production, and vehicle maintenance.  Diesel particulate pollutants are directly related to respiratory and heart disease.  Curently this is addressed with diesel particulate filters (DPF), devices that trap particulates and do not destroy them. Furthermore DPFs are prone to clogging, resulting in wasted fuel and costly engine maintenance. This project advances a non-thermal plasma (NTP) solution to destroy diesel particulates by converting them into non-hazardous compounds. NTP technology also has potential to be applied more broadly to power plant smoke stacks and other sources of particulate emissions.  The proposed solution will develop a NTP device for retrofitting diesel fleets, such as buses, waste haulers and utility trucks, improving engine performance and reducing operating costs. 

This SBIR Phase I project researches novel materials and components for use in a non-thermal plasma (NTP) reactor capable of withstanding the harsh conditions within the main exhaust stream of a diesel engine (e.g., 650 C temperatures and high exhaust flow). First generation NTP reactors capable of operating in low-temperature exhaust (e.g., 150 C) have already been developed and sold for use in diesel exhaust gas recirculation (EGR) systems; however, only about 30% to 50% of total diesel exhaust flows through EGR. The objective of this research is to demonstrate feasibility of NTP technology for use in the main exhaust stream to treat 100% of particulate emissions. The research plan will accurately characterize the working environment of the main diesel exhaust system and identify potential designs and parts/materials, creating hybrid or completely new components. Promising candidate components will be assembled into a prototype reactor and evaluated on an accelerated schedule to measure performance representing 6 months of typical operation. The system will be optimized for thermal, chemical, electrical, and mechanical performance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Paradigm of New York, LLC (Paradigm) is developing a plasma reactor system that eliminates carbon soot, also referred to as particulate matter (PM) from diesel engine exhaust. The Paradigm Plasma System (PPS) doesn't simply filter out these pollutants, it destroys the soot, reducing it to non-hazardous compounds (i.e., water vapor). Traditional PM control technologies such as diesel particulate filters are effective, but they are expensive to purchase and maintain, waste fuel through increased engine back pressure, and require soot burn-off or regeneration cycles. Furthermore, significant electrical energy is required to clean filters off-line in high temperature kilns, producing ash, which must be disposed of as hazardous waste.

 

In this Phase I SBIR project, Paradigm identified the characteristics required for a second generation PPS II reactor able to withstand the high-flow, high-temperature main exhaust system of a diesel engine, including the optimum design and best materials to solve the technical challenges associated with the intense thermal, mechanical, chemical, and electrical environment.  To meet this objective, Paradigm first defined the operating conditions in the main exhaust piping of heavy duty diesel engines, especially those on fleet vehicles such as buses, refuse collection trucks, and bucket trucks. These engines require high horsepower to operate and generate substantial amounts of carbon soot due to their harsh drive cycles. The resulting data on chemical composition, exhaust flow rates, pressures, and temperatures at all points along the exhaust system informed decisions on PPS II design, selection of materials, and optimum positioning in the exhaust streams.

 

A key outcome of Phase I is design of a reliable, modular high voltage (HV) connector, including electrically insulating potting and strut materials. High voltage, but very little current is required to generate the non-thermal plasma that converts hydrocarbons into benign compounds. The HV connector was designed to be a modular, quick connect device to facilitate ease of maintenance.  Paradigm then constructed, bench tested, and field tested a prototype reactor. 

 

The PPS II prototype system removed up to 87% of the carbon soot in the dirtiest and hottest diesel exhaust environments. Further design refinement and more power provision to the reactor is expected to achieve more than 98% carbon elimination. Optimization of the power supply and reactor geometry during Phase II will pave the way for full commercialization and production scale-up.

 

Paradigm's innovation will serve two broad customer segments: retrofit systems will be sold to diesel vehicle fleet managers to install on their existing vehicles, and OEM manufacturers will integrate it into their products prior to initial sale. Our initial target has become the retrofit market, specifically bus companies, refuse companies, utility companies, and short-haul trucking companies - representing an estimated 435,000 vehicles in the US and 1.3 million vehicles globally. The market is desperately looking for a solution to reduce carbon emissions and operating costs without sacrificing the power needed for their vehicles.

 

While the transition to electric vehicles is increasing for passenger cars and light duty trucks, high energy consumption vehicles in industries like agriculture, vegetation management, manufacturing, military, mining, road maintenance, public transportation, and utility vehicles require significantly more power and performance than is currently economically feasible with electric propulsion. As such, these heavy-duty vehicles will likely require diesel power for the foreseeable future. In fact, the diesel engine market is expanding. The demand for Class A diesel-powered trucks has increased significantly to keep up with demand for transporting goods directly to consumers from companies like Amazon as well as local food delivery services.  Paradigm's PPS II technology will dramatically reduce the amount of soot that these vehicles currently emit to the atmosphere, improving air quality particularly for populations living in urban inner city areas plagued by this contamination.
